0.prompt: How do B cells undergo affinity maturation during the germinal center reaction?
0.output: B cells undergo affinity maturation during the germinal center reaction by accumulating affinity-enhancing mutations in their IgV genes through several rounds of interzonal cycles. Germinal center B cells with the highest affinity are selected to recirculate to the dark zone for further division and somatic hypermutation (SHM), leading to their dominance in the population within a few days. T follicular helper (TFH) cells provide crucial signals to facilitate the selection and transit of high-affinity germinal center B cells.

Affinity maturation takes place in germinal
centers (GCs), defined mi croanatomical clusterscontaining up to a few thousand B cells that
emerge in multiple copies within secondary
lymphoid organs upon infe ction or immunization
(3–7). Each GC is traditionally viewed as arising
from a handful of independent “founder clones, ”
many of which are lost as affinity-based compe-tition leads to progressive focusing of the reper-toire on the most succe ssful progeny (which we
refer to as “homogenizing selection ”)(8). Although
it is inducible under experimental settings ( 9), the
extent to which homogenizing selection takesplace during normal immunization or infectionhas been difficult to determine, mostly due to
technical limitations in the methods used to
measure clonal diversity within individual GCs(10–14).

Frontiers in Microbiology | www.frontiersin.org 8 September 2017 | Volume 8 | Article 1693'), Document(metadata={'page': 0, 'source': '/nfs/turbo/umms-indikar/shared/projects/RAG/papers/DigitalLibrary-9-June-2024/Dynamics of B cells in germinal centres.pdf'}, page_content='S.\xa0De Silva and Ulf Klein
Abstract | Humoral immunity depends on the germinal centre (GC) reaction during  
which somatically mutated high-affinity memory B cells and plasma cells are generated. 
Recent studies have uncovered crucial cues that are required for the formation and the 
maintenance of GCs and for the selection of high-affinity antibody mutants. In addition,  
it is now clear that these events are promoted by the dynamic movements of cells within 
and between GCs. These findings have resolved the complexities of the GC reaction in 
greater detail than ever before. This Review focuses on these recent advances and 
discusses their implications for the establishment of humoral immunity.
REVIEWS
NATURE REVIEWS | IMMUNOLOGY   VOLUME 15  | MARCH 2015  | 137
 FOCUS ON 50 year S OF B Cell S

steps.input:
**INSTRUCTIONS**
You are an assistant responsible for compressing the important information in a document.
You will be given a users query and a piece of text. Summarize the text with the following aims:
1. remove information that is not complete ideas or unrelated to the topic of the user
2. improve the clarity of the writing and information
If there is no relevant information, say "None"

**USER QUERY**
How do B cells undergo affinity maturation during the germinal center reaction?

**TEXT**
the immunizing antigen. It has 
been known for a long time that GC -derived memory 
B cells and plasma cells express a highly selected anti -
body repertoire, the affinity of which increases over 
time. This phenomenon is known as affinity maturation  
and indicates the presence of effective selection processes 
within the GC that ensure that inferior antibody mutants 
or those with autoreactive specificities are outcompeted 
by higher affinity competitors. Antigen-specific memory 
B cells and plasma cells appear within 1 week after anti -
gen encounter4, which indicates that the GC reaction 
is remarkably efficient. This efficiency is facilitated by  
the specialized GC microenvironment that supports the 
close interaction and the rapid movements of various cell 
types in a confined space5. These features facilitate several 
iterative rounds of mutation and selection and, follow -
ing differentiation into post -GC cells, produce a stepwise 
increase in the antigen affinity of

**OUTPUT**
<put summary output here>
steps.output: content='B cells undergo affinity maturation during the germinal center reaction through a process where memory B cells and plasma cells develop a highly selected antibody repertoire with increasing affinity over time. This selection process ensures that inferior antibody mutants or those with autoreactive specificities are outcompeted by higher affinity competitors. Antigen-specific memory B cells and plasma cells appear within 1 week after antigen encounter, indicating the efficiency of the germinal center reaction. The specialized microenvironment of the germinal center supports close interaction and rapid movements of various cell types, facilitating iterative rounds of mutation and selection. This results in a stepwise increase in antigen affinity.' response_metadata={'token_usage': {'completion_tokens': 126, 'prompt_tokens': 313, 'total_tokens': 439, 'completion_tokens_details': {'reasoning_tokens': 0}}, 'model_name': 'gpt-3.5-turbo-0125', 'system_fingerprint': None, 'finish_reason': 'stop', 'logprobs': None, 'time': 1.7994277477264404, 'call back': {'Total Tokens': 439, 'Prompt Tokens': 313, 'Completion Tokens': 126, 'Total Cost (USD)': 0.0003455}} id='run-633f446e-bdeb-44eb-becb-7cce0bd56d58-0' usage_metadata={'input_tokens': 313, 'output_tokens': 126, 'total_tokens': 439}
steps.parsedOutput: B cells undergo affinity maturation during the germinal center reaction through a process where memory B cells and plasma cells develop a highly selected antibody repertoire with increasing affinity over time. This selection process ensures that inferior antibody mutants or those with autoreactive specificities are outcompeted by higher affinity competitors. Antigen-specific memory B cells and plasma cells appear within 1 week after antigen encounter, indicating the efficiency of the germinal center reaction. The specialized microenvironment of the germinal center supports close interaction and rapid movements of various cell types, facilitating iterative rounds of mutation and selection. This results in a stepwise increase in antigen affinity.

had considerably more affinity-enhancing mutations in 
their IgV genes compared with their less proliferative 
competitors. This indicates a mechanism by which affin -
ity maturation is achieved following several rounds of 
interzonal cycles. In a ‘feedforward’ loop, the GC B cells

culate to the dark zone to undergo further rounds of divi -
sion and SHM. As a result of this iterative process, GC 
B cells with the highest affinity dominate the population 
of B cells participating in the GC reaction within only a 
few days following the initiation of the GC reaction.The findings described above show that TFH cells 
provide crucial signals to high-affinity GC B cells to 
facilitate their selection, and their transit back to and 
division in the dark zone (TFH cells have been thor -
oughly reviewed elsewhere76,77). The exact nature of 
these signals remains unclear and is being actively

**INSTRUCTIONS**
You are an assistant responsible for compressing the important information in a document.
You will be given a users query and a piece of text. Summarize the text with the following aims:

**USER QUERY**
How do B cells undergo affinity maturation during the germinal center reaction?

**TEXT**
antibodies over time, which is essential fortheir effectiveness in curtailing and preventinginfection.
Affinity maturation takes place in germinal
centers (GCs), defined mi croanatomical clusterscontaining up to a few thousand B cells that
emerge in multiple copies within secondary
lymphoid organs upon infe ction or immunization
(3–7). Each GC is traditionally viewed as arising
from a handful of independent “founder clones, ”
many of which are lost as affinity-based compe-tition leads to progressive focusing of the reper-toire on the most succe ssful progeny (which we
refer to as “homogenizing selection ”)(8). Although
it is inducible under experimental settings ( 9), the
extent to which homogenizing selection takesplace during normal immunization or infectionhas been difficult to determine, mostly due to
technical limitations in the methods used to
measure clonal diversity within individual GCs(10–14).
Measuring clonal diversity in GCs usingmultiphoton microscopy
As an approach to

**OUTPUT**
<put summary output here>
steps.output: content='B cells undergo affinity maturation during the germinal center reaction, where microanatomical clusters of B cells emerge in secondary lymphoid organs upon infection or immunization. Founder clones compete based on affinity, leading to a focusing of the repertoire on successful progeny. Homogenizing selection plays a role in this process. Technical limitations have made it difficult to determine the extent of homogenizing selection during normal immunization or infection.' response_metadata={'token_usage': {'completion_tokens': 86, 'prompt_tokens': 347, 'total_tokens': 433, 'completion_tokens_details': {'reasoning_tokens': 0}}, 'model_name': 'gpt-3.5-turbo-0125', 'system_fingerprint': None, 'finish_reason': 'stop', 'logprobs': None, 'time': 1.3279390335083008, 'call back': {'Total Tokens': 433, 'Prompt Tokens': 347, 'Completion Tokens': 86, 'Total Cost (USD)': 0.0003025}} id='run-2ede393c-b2d3-45ae-aeb7-2b1e67db5176-0' usage_metadata={'input_tokens': 347, 'output_tokens': 86, 'total_tokens': 433}
steps.parsedOutput: B cells undergo affinity maturation during the germinal center reaction, where microanatomical clusters of B cells emerge in secondary lymphoid organs upon infection or immunization. Founder clones compete based on affinity, leading to a focusing of the repertoire on successful progeny. Homogenizing selection plays a role in this process. Technical limitations have made it difficult to determine the extent of homogenizing selection during normal immunization or infection.

steps.input:
**INSTRUCTIONS**
You are an assistant responsible for compressing the important information in a document.
You will be given a users query and a piece of text. Summarize the text with the following aims:
1. remove information that is not complete ideas or unrelated to the topic of the user
2. improve the clarity of the writing and information
If there is no relevant information, say "None"

**USER QUERY**
How do B cells undergo affinity maturation during the germinal center reaction?

**TEXT**
S. De Silva and Ulf Klein
Abstract | Humoral immunity depends on the germinal centre (GC) reaction during  
which somatically mutated high-affinity memory B cells and plasma cells are generated. 
Recent studies have uncovered crucial cues that are required for the formation and the 
maintenance of GCs and for the selection of high-affinity antibody mutants. In addition,  
it is now clear that these events are promoted by the dynamic movements of cells within 
and between GCs. These findings have resolved the complexities of the GC reaction in 
greater detail than ever before. This Review focuses on these recent advances and 
discusses their implications for the establishment of humoral immunity.
REVIEWS
NATURE REVIEWS | IMMUNOLOGY   VOLUME 15  | MARCH 2015  | 137
 FOCUS ON 50 year S OF B Cell S
© 2015 Macmillan Publishers Limited. All rights reserved

**OUTPUT**
<put summary output here>
steps.output: content='The germinal center reaction is crucial for the generation of high-affinity memory B cells and plasma cells. Recent studies have revealed important cues for the formation and maintenance of germinal centers, as well as the selection of high-affinity antibody mutants. Dynamic cell movements within and between germinal centers play a key role in these processes. These findings have provided a better understanding of the germinal center reaction and its implications for humoral immunity.' response_metadata={'token_usage': {'completion_tokens': 87, 'prompt_tokens': 314, 'total_tokens': 401, 'completion_tokens_details': {'reasoning_tokens': 0}}, 'model_name': 'gpt-3.5-turbo-0125', 'system_fingerprint': None, 'finish_reason': 'stop', 'logprobs': None, 'time': 1.8314623832702637, 'call back': {'Total Tokens': 401, 'Prompt Tokens': 314, 'Completion Tokens': 87, 'Total Cost (USD)': 0.0002875}} id='run-cbe9ce9c-48fa-4943-a57d-e15a9af9d95b-0' usage_metadata={'input_tokens': 314, 'output_tokens': 87, 'total_tokens': 401}
steps.parsedOutput: The germinal center reaction is crucial for the generation of high-affinity memory B cells and plasma cells. Recent studies have revealed important cues for the formation and maintenance of germinal centers, as well as the selection of high-affinity antibody mutants. Dynamic cell movements within and between germinal centers play a key role in these processes. These findings have provided a better understanding of the germinal center reaction and its implications for humoral immunity.

steps.input: How do B cells undergo affinity maturation during the germinal center reaction?
steps.output:
{'input_documents': {0: {'page_content': 'Source: Dynamics of B cells in germinal centres.pdf
Content: B cells undergo affinity maturation during the germinal center reaction through a process where memory B cells and plasma cells develop a highly selected antibody repertoire with increasing affinity over time. This selection process ensures that inferior antibody mutants or those with autoreactive specificities are outcompeted by higher affinity competitors. Antigen-specific memory B cells and plasma cells appear within 1 week after antigen encounter, indicating the efficiency of the germinal center reaction. The specialized microenvironment of the germinal center supports close interaction and rapid movements of various cell types, facilitating iterative rounds of mutation and selection. This results in a stepwise increase in antigen affinity.', 'metadata': {'source': "{'page': 0, 'source': '/nfs/turbo/umms-indikar/shared/projects/RAG/papers/DigitalLibrary-9-June-2024/Dynamics of B cells in germinal centres.pdf'}"}}, 1: {'page_content': 'Source: Dynamics of B cells in germinal centres.pdf
Content: None', 'metadata': {'source': "{'page': 10, 'source': '/nfs/turbo/umms-indikar/shared/projects/RAG/papers/DigitalLibrary-9-June-2024/Dynamics of B cells in germinal centres.pdf'}"}}, 2: {'page_content': 'Source: Dynamics of B cells in germinal centres.pdf
Content: B cells undergo affinity maturation during the germinal center reaction by accumulating affinity-enhancing mutations in their IgV genes through several rounds of interzonal cycles. GC B cells with the highest affinity are instructed to recirculate to the dark zone for further division and SHM, leading to their dominance in the population within a few days. TFH cells provide crucial signals to facilitate the selection and transit of high-affinity GC B cells, although the exact nature of these signals is still being investigated.', 'metadata': {'source': "{'page': 6, 'source': '/nfs/turbo/umms-indikar/shared/projects/RAG/papers/DigitalLibrary-9-June-2024/Dynamics of B cells in germinal centres.pdf'}"}}, 3: {'page_content': 'Source: Regulated selection of germinal-center cells into the memory B cell compartment.pdf

Content: B cells undergo affinity maturation during the germinal center reaction, where microanatomical clusters of B cells emerge in secondary lymphoid organs upon infection or immunization. Germinal center B cells with the highest affinity are selected to recirculate to the dark zone for further division and somatic hypermutation (SHM), leading to their dominance in the population within a few days. steps.parsedOutput: B cells undergo affinity maturation during the germinal center reaction by accumulating affinity-enhancing mutations in their IgV genes through several rounds of interzonal cycles. Germinal center B cells with the highest affinity are selected to recirculate to the dark zone for further division and somatic hypermutation (SHM), leading to their dominance in the population within a few days. T follicular helper (TFH) cells provide crucial signals to facilitate the selection and transit of high-affinity germinal center B cells.
